agreed it is clearer. for me it's obvious that it is the same. Also, you
might want to make that "catch (Throwable t)"

On this point, does anybody here catches Throwables inside his code?

I do. Even if not *supposed* to. Because when I "try" something, I want
nothing to crap out except possibly that thing, and I want to know about it.

For exemple, if there is a classpath problem preventing me to do X(), I want
to catch the NoClassDefFoundError, log the error, and invoke my recovery
strategy (msg to user, alternate method, etc..), Not let the error go all
the way to the top and possibly stop some important top-level task (or worse
the entire jvm process).

mathieu

> > there are some cases when it's "ok" to have no assert* or fail. For
example:
> >
> > public void testMethod() {
> >       Obj.method("abc");  //test that it does not throw anything and
accept
> > the param.
> >   }
>
> maybe
>
>    pubic void testMethod() {
>       try {
>          Obj.method("abc");
>       } catch (Exception e) {
>          fail("shouldn't throw any exception");
>       }
>    }
>
> better tells what you want to test.

This is one of the rare times when the extra code to catch Exception is
useful. Excellent advice.
